head.title: Keep Hanford's Radiation Risk in Perspective; Hazardous Uranium

hedline.hl1: Keep Hanford's Radiation Risk in Perspective; Hazardous Uranium

block.p: Tom Bailie's ''Growing Up as a Nuclear Guinea Pig'' (Op-Ed, July 22) brought tears to our eyes, tears of sorrow as well as of hope that the chicanery of the international nuclear cartel will be exposed.

Tragically, Mr. Bailie's story is one of many of pain, exploitation and death by the nuclear industry. The myth of ''clean,'' environmentally friendly nuclear power is diabolical propaganda: studies show that it doesn't reduce global warming, that it's exceedingly uneconomical when all costs are made known and that its wastes present an unmanageable and perpetual hazard to all life.

Suffering begins not only with an accidental or deliberate radiation release from a nuclear plant or bomb, but also with the mining of uranium. Uranium's destructive properties are unleashed the moment it's taken from the ground. The first victims are usually indigenous people: Australian aborigines, sub-Arctic Siberian tribes, Namibians, South Africans and North American Indians.

Globally, uranium mining devastates the homes of indigenous peoples, contaminates their food and water, destroys their traditional lives and cultures, makes them public wards and reduces their sacred places to restricted dump sites.

When uranium and its isotopic radioactivity is released, whether at Chernobyl, Three Mile Island, Bikini, Hanford, the Saskatchewan mines or Hiroshima, suffering and death are inevitable. Millions of people have been victims of the brief 45-year-old manipulation of uranium.
Uranium mining represents an unparalleled threat to life on earth. Un-less uranium stays in the ground, we may all take its place - sooner, not later.
The writer is on the staff of the World Uranium Hearing.
